title: Net force from graph of potential energy

content.description: The graph above shows the potential energy <math alttext="U" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a system as one object in the system moves along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis and the rest of the system does not move. Six evenly-spaced points along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis are labeled. At point <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the object is moving in the positive <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-direction and the mechanical energy of the system is <math alttext="5.0 joules" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>5.0 J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. As the object moves, no energy enters or leaves the system.
content.question: In which segment does the net force exerted on the object have the greatest magnitude?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
